pros: Always willing to work with your schedule

pros: - Friendly faculty and staff - Faculty and staff love the school and the students - Faculty and Staff work very hard with limited resources - Hybrid work environment for some - Beautiful campus - Employees can use the fitness facilities - Cyclical busy seasons and workflows
cons: - VPs and above are pitted against one another and/or bully one another; lack of alignment at times - Salaries are not very competitive, especially for those who have not been recently hired - Lack of annual performance reviews and compensation adjustments - Accrual of time off and sick time is very slow - No remote-first benefits are offered - Antiquated processes and proceedures (or lack thereof) - Grind culture is perpetuated in some departments - Limited budgets and resources are awarded to some departments - Enrollment/Admissions dept is favored - Employees have to pay for parking - A lot of multitasking and re-prioritizing due to a lack of planning and direction (competing priorities) among senior staff + the board

pros: Great benefits, nice location, clean campus
cons: Hostile working environment, not paid livable wages, and favoritism towards employees who identify as alums of the institution.

pros: Very strong leadership on the academic side Great people and a beautiful campus Changes being put in place will position the college well for the future
cons: Facing many of the same challenges as other smaller, private colleges are facing nationwide Salaries on the lower side, but offset by good benefits

review_title: High Hours, Low Pay, Little Respect
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Moraga, CA
pros: General autonomy, beautiful campus, most students driven to succeed and fun to teach
cons: Adjunct faculty are the true workhorses of the school. Paid very badly, and the step system is ridiculous for adjuncts. Your department will require TOP NOTCH teaching for insanely low wages, then they'll give you lip service once in awhile to act like they care. Tenure track faculty don't care about you--that fact is very clear and you are on the bottom rungs of their social hierarchy. There's no way to work your way up in this system because there is a clear salary ceiling that just won't go any higher for the fee per course. You can't survive off of this income, and adjuncts were the first to get chopped when covid hit (had fewer courses to teach) and some in my department were even told they had no choice when it came to how they taught (in person or online) if they wanted to keep their jobs.

pros: Small class sizes, intimate community
cons: No retirement contributions, DEI talk, little action. Well intentioned, but lacks effective leadership

pros:
- *Most* employees are passionate about the mission and are truly there to support students.

- Supporting students is a positive experience.
cons:
- Employees are overworked, underpaid and burnt out. Many are working 1-3 jobs because job requisitions are not filled after someone retires or leaves.

- College is in financial crisis. Your job is never secure because job cuts are always a possibility. 

- Policies & procedures are antiquated. 

- There’s a lack of training for new employees.

- The previous Administrations have exhibited poor communication to staff and faculty. ( An example was the sudden rollout of updated vacation and sick leave policy. HR adjusted only due to the backlash.)

- Communication to students is also poor. In the Summer of 2020, students were promised in person classes, only to renig 2 weeks before the first day of school, when ALL other colleges planned, realistically, to move to remote learning.

- Faculty often treat Staff as “less than”.

review_title: Great team, good benefits, low wages
pros: Beautiful place to work. Mission driven work. Great collaborative team. Management does not micromanage your work. Amazing PTO (paid holidays, sick, and vacation time from day 1). Employer retirement contribution - about 7% (but starts at year 1).
cons: Low salary for the Bay Area and compared to other offices on campus. Colleagues have left admissions to work elsewhere on campus; reported they were making more money and doing less work.  You will be expected to work nights and weekends for events. Although we have vacation time, we can’t use it during “black out” times from September to May — which is a long stretch of time. Not many professional development opportunities. Tuition benefit (only 1 free class per term).

review_title: Beautiful collegiate campus in the sleepy town or Moraga
pros:
The community and values of the staff, faculty, and students - they really make it a priority to "listen" to you and give you their attention. Great quality education at a private, liberal arts college that is focused on educating the whole person and focus on global social responsibility.

Competitive salary and benefits for working at a high quality school.
cons:
The same issues as at other higher education institutions - Too many departments and database systems that don't necessarily work well together. The leadership also needs to do a better job touting the strengths of this campus. Then again, you get a quality education here because of the smaller size of classes, so maybe that's not the best approach.

IT and HR could also use some help, but again, there are always small pockets of unprofessionalism and incompetence on any university campus. It is improving, though!

pros: Great benefits. A sense of mission, a collegial environment, and academic freedom. This is a place to gain experience and move on from. You can do a lot with a little here that will catapult you forward in your career.
cons: Saint Mary's is much better for faculty than staff. Staff at the college are a more diverse body than faculty and the socio-econimic divide between the two groups is palpable. Faculty tend to be administratively in charge of staff, yet are out of touch with administrative realities. There isn't a lot of mentorship or upward mobility for staff, especially female staff. They hire a lot of alumni, which doesn't promote diversity of perspectives. Compensation is not competitive compared to other sf bay area colleges.

pros: The managers for the most part here really care about their students on a personal level and want to get to know you and see you succeed. Good culture and the management for the most part knows how to run a ship.
cons: At least that's what they say, but will never give you a raise. If you need a job to afford college, you might consider looking around the bay if you have reliable transportation; you won't be able to afford rent if you want to live locally. Don't even try to afford living on campus via an on campus job.

review_title: Good place, a lot of work, limited resources
pros: As long as you build positive relationships across campus and fulfill your commitments, people are very nice and try their best to support your work. Students are great to work with!
cons: A lot of offices are under-staffed, while others are over-staffed. For those under-staffed offices, there really isn't any vision of supporting those offices. You are just asked to do more and more with less and less. With that being said, if you build good relationships across campus, people can be really supportive.

review_title: Caring community of faculty, staff and administrators. Diverse, engaged student population. Strong mission. Low pay.
pros: Saint Mary's is beautiful, friendly, student-centered, collegial and communal. Work there long enough, and you'll become part of "the family." Workplace culture is positive, and as a long-time staff member I was well supported by my colleagues and supervisors. SMC students are generally wonderful to work with, and those who are truly seeking it will find a high-quality liberal arts education and lots of out-of-class opportunities for growth and exploration. As a staff member I was a supervisor, advisor, counselor and teacher to undergraduates and developed positive, meaningful relationships with many. I also worked closely with fellow staff, dozens of faculty members and upper-level administrators and my experiences were generally positive. My department was led by people with vision and I was encouraged to grow professionally and personally.
cons: Low pay as compared to similar jobs in other institutions. Quality of leadership and management in departments across campus varies pretty greatly, so paying attention to the qualifications and qualities of those who are actually interviewing you is key. As a smaller, more communal workplace, personal relationships are valued but professionalism (follow-through, strategic planning, consistent communication) is sometimes lacking. Change often moves at a glacial pace (often true of higher education work environments!). Technology/IT issues have persisted in the past but that looks to be improving. Can be a "small town" type of work environment, so potential employees MUST be relational and know how to learn and acclimate to the social and political landscape.

review_title: There's a shared commitment to the mission of the organization among personnel and opportunities to collaborate.
pros: There is a genuine sense of community, a commitment to mission, a strong emphasis on work-life balance, and opportunities for professional development. The administration rewards creativity, innovation and leadership.
cons: Salaries across the board are about 5% below average for the Bay Area, there can be an 'us vs. them' mentality among some departments. The organization has bounced back after the recession and has a good outlook for the years ahead.

pros: Nice campus and great students.
cons: Lack of effective communication between administration and faculty. Lack of leadership from members of faculty and administration that are also members of clergy. Incompetent HR. Academic departments are often at cross-purposes and decisions are left to those who specialize in political backbiting. Ultimately, the college suffers from lack of a larger "mission" and morale suffers as a result.

review_title: A management made of exhausted retirees disinterested in improving the institution
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Moraga, CA
pros: Old-fashioned beautiful campus, top-notch sport facilities, location.
cons: Low salaries (for the area) mostly attract incompetent employees. Retired administrators just pose for events' pictures and send  occasional emails.  Loosing students very quickly from low enrollment and by transfers. Reluctant to academic innovation. Non-supportive to faculty, treating them with unbelievable academic brutality. Fake values and beliefs. Is all about money.

review_title: IT Services: Safe environment, but students are expendable...
job_title: Senior Technology Consultant in Moraga, CA
pros: Saint Mary's College of California IT Services has made a lot of improvements in my three years here, but overall, the improvement has been minimal. Just the other month, sick leave hours were added as the first and only benefit student workers receive. Many of the managers are nice people, overall, who are passionate about their work.
cons:
Being a student worker at Saint Mary's College can be very stressful, financially. Many of my coworkers, including myself, depend on the money we earn through ITS to pay for our rent, books, food, ect. One would think that a prestigious liberal arts college would have the outlook to give struggling students a living wage, but this is entirely false. When the statewide minimum wage went up the summer of 2014, Saint Mary's increased their pay scale to agree with the new legal system. However, any student workers that had been on minimum wage before ($8) and had either earned a raise or who had nearly worked enough hours for a raise, lost all progress. Students that had been making $8.50 were now making $9, but so were those who were only making $8. I was now training workers, who would go on to train another generation of workers, with all of us making $9 an hour. For a two years I petitioned for a raise, and continued making minimum wage until I put in my two-weeks notice. I finally received a raise to $10.50 after working nearly three full years for Saint Mary's. One can only imagine the stress this put on me, trying to afford Bay Area housing costs and having to put my only job on the line to get a raise.

In summary: Saint Mary's College, especially IT Services, cares very little about you as a person if you are a student worker. I highly recommend finding a job nearby off campus instead, if you can afford to commute.

pros: I worked in both the undergraduate and graduate schools of education. I found the students to be wonderful and a pleasure to teach. I didn't deal much with the admin but I didn't think too much about them. I showed up, taught, held office hours, and went home. It was a nice little gig.
cons: Salary was a bit tough and it seems impossible to make a living as an adjunct. I thought some of the students needed more academic support than I could provide as a adjunct (i.e. not there during the daytime) and that was frustrating.

pros: Beautiful campus and environment.  Most staff and faculty are pleasant people to work with.
cons: Compensation is way too low to sustain career employees.  Tradition in the way of progress and communication is lacking.  Too many silos and political agendas.
